row.Body:
Can someone explain to me how there can be different kinds of infinities?

I was reading "the man who loved only numbers" and came across the concept of countable and uncountable infinities, but they're only words to me.

Any help would be appreciated.
row.Title: Different kinds of infinities?

row.Body: This limit thing keeps coming up in my calculus textbook. What is it?
row.Title: What is a limit?

row.Body: mathfactor is one I listen to. Does anyone else have a recommendation?
row.Title: List of interesting math podcasts?

row.Body: More or Less is a BBC Radio 4 programme about maths and statistics in the news, and there is a free podcast. It's presented by Tim Harford, the Undercover Economist from the Financial Times.

I have read a few proofs that $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational.

I have never, however, been able to really grasp what they were talking about.

Is there a simplified proof that $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational?
row.Title: How can you prove that the square root of two is irrational?

row.Body: I'm looking for a nice, quick online graphing tool. The ability to link to, or embed the output would be handy, too.
row.Title: What is your favorite online graphing tool?

row.Body: You use a proof by contradiction. Basically, you suppose that $\sqrt{2}$ can be written as $p/q$. Then you know that $2q^2 = p^2$. However, both $q^2$ and $p^2$ have an even number of factors of two, so $2q^2$ has an odd number of factors of 2, which means it can't be equal to $p^2$.

I was reading up on the Fibonacci Sequence when I've noticed some were able to calculate specific numbers. So far I've only figured out creating an array and counting to the value, which is incredibly simple, but I reckon I can't find any formula for calculating a Fibonacci number based on it's position.

Is there a way to do this? If so, how are we able to apply these formulas to arrays?
row.Title: How are we able to calculate specific numbers in the Fibonacci Sequence?
